VII. 134 137 49
discharges itself into the Zouga -
and the TeouheTeoughe (TeougeTeoughe) into the
Lake - The flow begins either in
March or April and the descending
waters ˄ find the channels of all these
Qu:Query meaning -
not clear. rivers ˄ dried out except in certain pools in
their beds which have
long dry
spaces
between
them The Lake itself is very
low - the Zouga is but a prolongation
of the Tamunakle and ˄ and an arm of
the Lake reaches up to the point
where the one ends and the other begins
This last is narrow and shallow
while the Zouga is broad and deep
Thise narrow arm of the Lake which
on the map looks like a continuation of the Zouga
has never been observed to flow
either way - It is as stagnant as
the Lake itself - The TeougeTeoughe flows
into and Tamunakle being essentially
the same river and recievingreceiving
their supplies from the same source
(the Embarrah) Varra can never outrun
each other - If either could, or if
the Teoughe could fill the Lake, a
thing which has never happened in
modern times Then this little arm
would prove a convenient
escapement to prevent inundation
If the Lake ever becomes lower
than the bed of the Zouga a little
of the water of the TeougaTeoughe Tamunakle
might flow into it instead of down
the Zouga we should then have
the phenomenon of a river flowing
two ways - but this has never
135 138 50
been observed to take place here and
it is doubtful if ˄ it ever can occur - ˄ in this locality - The
Zouga is broad and deep when it
leaves the Tamunakle but becomes
gradually narrower as you
descend about 200 miles - There
it flows into Kumadau a small
lake of about 3 or four miles broad
and 12 long - The water which
higher up began to flow in April
does not make much progress in
filling this till the end of June
In August ˄ & September they ˄ the rivers cease to flow
When the supply has been more
than usually abundant a little water
flows beyond Kumadau in the
bed first seen by us inon the 4th July
and if great
in quantity
might go
farther in and we have seen the dry rocky
bed of the Zouga since ˄ seen but still
farther to the East - The whole
Qu:Query omit
sense not clear phenomenon The water
supply of this part of the
river system, as will be more
fully explained farther on, takes
place in channels prepared for
a much more copious water flow
It resembles a deserted Eastern garden
in which where all ˄ the embankments &
canals ˄ for irrigation arecan be traced but ˄ where the
main dam and sluices being lefthaving been
allowed to get out of repair, only a small portion
can now be laid under water
In the case of the Zouga the
channel is perfect but water
enough to filllfill the whole channel
never comes down, and before
136 139
it finds its way much beyond
Kumadau the upper supply
ceases to run and the rest becomes
evaporated - the higher
parts of its
bed even
are much
broader &
more capacious
than the
lower towards
Kamadau # There is no such
thing in the country as a river
running into sand and becoming
lost - This phenomenon so
convenient for Geographers
haunted my fancy for years
and as I have failed in discovering
anything except a most insignificant
approach to it I begin ˄ now to doubt
its reality -

My chief object in coming
to the Lake was to visit Sebituane
the great chief of the Makololo who
was reported to live some 200
miles beyond - We had now
come to a half tribe of the Bamang-
-wato called Batauana. underTheir chief was
a young man named Lechulatébe
Sebituane had conquered his father
Moremi, and Lechulatébe recievedreceived
part of his education ˄ while a captive among
the Bakoba Bayeiye - His uncle
a sensible man ransomed him
and having collected a number
of families together abdicated the
chieftainship in favour of his
nephew - As Lechulatebe had
first come into power he
imagined that the proper way
of shewingshowing his abilities was
to act directly contrary to every
thing that his uncle advised
137 140
When we came the uncle recommended
handsome treatment, therefore the
hopeful youth presented us with
a goat only - It ought to have been
an ox - So I proposed to ˄ to my companions to loose
the animal and let him go as
a hint to his master - My com-
-panions They however did not
wish to insult him - I being more
of a native thought "he began it"
We wished to purchase some
goats or oxen - Lechulatebe
offered us elephants' tusks -
"No we cannot eat these - we
want something to fill our stomachs"
"Neither can I, But I seehear you
white men are all very fond of these bones
so I offer them, I want to
put the goats into my own stomach"
A trader who accompanied us
was then purchasing ivory at
the rate of ten good large tusks
for a musket worth thirteen shillings
They were called "bones" and
I myself saw eight casesinstances in
which the tusks had been
left to rot with the other bones
where of the elephant where he fell -
The Batauana never had a
chance of a market before - but
in less than two years afterward
after our discovery not a man
of them could be found who
was not keenly alive to the
great value preciousness of the article

On the day after our arrival at
the Lake I applied to Lechulatebe
for guides to Sebituane, As he
was much afraid of that
chief he objected on the score
of fearing lest other white men
wshould go the thither also and give
Sebituane guns, butwhereas if the
traders came to him alone the
possession of firearms would
give him such a superiority
that Sebituane would be
afraid of him - It was in
vain to explain that I would
inculcate peace between them. - that
Sebituane had been a father to
him and Sechele, and was as
anxious to see me as he ˄ (Lechulatebe) had been
He offered to give me as much
ivory as I needed without
going to that chief - But when
weI refused to take any he
unwillingly consented to give
guides - Next day however
when OswelOswell and I were prepared
to start with the horses only, we
recievedreceived a senseless refusal
& Like like He, Sekomi - like, ˄ he sent men to
the Bayeiye with orders to refuse
us passage accross the river -
Trying to form a raft at a
narrow part I worked many
hours in the water but the dry
wood was so worm eaten
139 142
it would not bear the weight of a
single person - I was not then
aware of the numbers of alligators
which exist in the Zouga and
never remember my labour in
the water without feeling thankful
that I escaped their jaws, The
season was now far advanced
and as Mr OOswel, with his wonted generous
feelings volunteered on the spot to
go down to the Cape and bring up
a boat we resolved to make our
way South again -

Coming down the Zouga
we havde now time to look at
its banks - These are very beautiful
resembling closely many parts
of the ever lovely River Clyde above
Glasgow, The structure ˄ formation is soft
calcareous tufa such as forms
the bottom of all this basin -
Perpendicular on the side to
which the water swings and
sloping and grassy on the other -
on The slopes ˄ are selected for the pitfalls designed
by the Bayeiye to entrap the
animals as they come to drink
They are about seven ˄ or eight feet deep
Three or four feet wide at the
mouth and gradually decreasing
till they are ˄ only about a foot wide
at the bottom - The mouth is square
an oblong square (the only square thing made by
the Bechuanas for everything
else is round) and the long
140 143 55
diameter at the surface is about
equal to the depth - The decreasing
width towards the bottom is
intended to make the animal wedge
himself more firmly in by his
weight and struggles - They are
usually in pairs with a wall
of a foot in diameterthick between
them ends of each - A drawing of two oblong boxes slightly apart, representing a pair of traps with a wall between them. So
that if the beast should save
himself by striding the hind legs
he would he springs forward to save himself
and leaps into the second with
a force which insures the precipitationfall
of thehis whole body into the trap - They
are covered with great care
all the ˄ excavated ground is removed to a
distance - so as not to excite suspicion
A coveringceiling is made of reeds &
grass above these the sand is
thrown and watered so as to
appear exactly like the rest of
the spot - Some of our party
plumped into them more than
once even when in search of
them in order to open them
to prevent the loss of our cattle
If an ox sees a hole he carefully
avoids it And old Elephants
have been known to precede
the herd and whisk off the coverings
of the pitfalls on each side of him
all the way down to the water
We have seen instances in which
the old ofamong these sagacious animals had
141 144
actually lifted the young out of the
trap

The animals which abound in
the country ajdacentadjacent -

The trees which adorn the banks
are magnificent - Two enormous
Baobabs (Adansonia digitata) or Mo˄uanas groEw at the spot where we
took the observations for the
Latitude (20° 20' - SSouth) - The Longitude of the Lake
has nevernot been ascertained as our watches
were useless - It may be between 22° & 23°E.East)
The largest of these ˄ trees was 76 feet in
girth - The Palmyra appears here
and there among the trees not met
within the South - The Mokuchong
or Mashoma bears an edible
fruit of indifferent quality but
the tree itself would be a fine
specimen of arboreal beauty in
Qu:Query this word any part of the world - The bole
is often converted into canoes,
The Motsouri, which bears
a scarlet plum containing a
pleasant acid juice, resembling
an orange tree byin its dark ˄ ever green
foliage and a cypress by in
its form - Wild We were there
in the winter and saw nothing of
the flora - The plants and bushes
were dry - But wild Indigo abounded
as indeed it does over large tracts
of country of Africa - It is called
Mohetolo or the "changer" by the
boys who dye their ornaments of
142 145
straw with the juice - There are two kinds
of cotton in the country and the
Mashona who convert it into cloth
dye it blue with this plant -

We found the elephants in prodigious
numbers on the southern bank - They
came to drink by night and - after having
slaked their thirst - in doing which
they throw large quantities ˄ of water over
themselves and scream with
delight - they shewshowevince their horror of
pitfalls by setting off in a straight
line to the desert and never diverge
till they are eight or ten miles off
They are smaller here than in theythe
countries farther south - At the Limpopo
for instance they are upwards
of twelve feet high here only eleven
Farther North we shall find
them nine ˄ feet only - The Khoodoo or
tolo seemed smaller too than
those we had been accustomed to
We saw specimens of the Kuabaōba
or straight horned Rhinoceros
a variety of the white
and found that from the horn
being projected downwards it
did not obstruct the line of
vision and make itso that this species was enabled
to be much more wary that its
neighbour - --

We discovered an entirely
new species of antelope called
Lechē or Lechui - It is a beautiful
143 146
water antelope of a ˄ light brownish yellow colour
Its horns, - exactly like those of the
aigoceros ellipsiprimnus - or water
buck or Tumōga of the Bechuanas, -
rise from the head with a slight
bend back wards then curve forwards
at the points, The chest, belly and
orbits are nearly white, the front
of the legs & ankles deep brown - From
the horns along the nape to the withers
the male has a small mane and
the tail of the same yellowish colour
with the rest of the skin and
the tail has a tuft of black hair -
HeIt is never found far from a mile from water
- Islets in marshes & swamps are hisits
favourite haunts and weit is
quite unknown except in the
central humid basin of Africa
Having a good deal of curiosity
it he haspresents a noble appearance as
heit stands gazing with head erect
at the approaching stranger - When
it he resolves to decamp hite puts
lowers hitsis head and lays his
horns down to a level with the
withers - ˄ he then begins with a
waddling trot which ends in
a gallop and springing over
bushes like the Pallahs - He It
runs invariably ˄ runs to the water
and crosses it by a succession
of bounds - each of which
appears to be from the bottom
We thought the flesh good at first
but soon got tired of it -

144 147
Great shoals of excellent fish
come down annually with the
access of waters The Mullet
Mugil Africanus is the most abundant

The Glanis Siluris a large
broad-headed fish without
scales and barbed called
by the natives "Mosala" attains
an enormous size and
fatness - They are caught so
large ˄ that when a man carries
one over his shoulder the tail
reaches the ground - It is a
vegetable feeder and in many
of its habits resembles the eel -
# Another
closely resembling ˄ This fish is named Clarias
capensis by Dr Smith - It is
widely diffused throughout
the Interior and often leaves
the rivers for the sake of
feeding in pools - As these
dry up large numbers of them
are entrapped by the natives
145 148 60
A water serpent yellow spotted
and dark brown is often
seen swimming along with
his head above the water
HeIt is quite innocuous and
is relished ˄ as food by the BayeyeBayeiye

They mention ten kinds of
fish in their river and in
their songs of praise of the Zouga
say, "the messenger sent
in haste is always forced to
spend the night in the way by the
abundance of food you place
before him"

The Bayeiye live much on
fish which is quite an abomination
to the Bechuanas in the South and
they catch them in large numbers
by means of nets made of the
fine strong fibres of the Hibiscus
which grows abundantly in
all moist places - Their float
ropes are made of the Ifé or
146 149
as it is ˄ now called, the Sanseviere angolensis - a
flag looking plant having a very
strong fibre that abounds from
Kolobeng to Angola, and the floats
themselves are pieces of a water
plant containing valves
at each joint which retain the
air in cells about an inch long
The ˄ mode of knotting of the nets is identical
with our own mode.

They also spear the fish with
Javelins spears having a light handle
which readily floats on the
surface - - AndThey shewshow great
dexterity in harpooning the
hippopotamus - & The barbed blade ˄
of the spear being attached to a rope
of the young leaves of the
palmyra The animal cannot
rid himself of the canoe attached
to him in whale fashion except
by smashing it which he
not unfrequentlyinfrequently does by
his teeth or by a stroke of
his hind foot

On returning to the Bakurutse
we found that their canoes
were simply large bundles of
reeds tied together - TheseSuch a canoe would
be a ready extemporaneous
pontoon for crossing any
147 150
a river with ˄ that had reedy banks

Having returned to Kolobeng I and
remained there till April of 1850, I and
then left in company with Mrs LLivingstone and
our three children with the
Chief Sechele
who had now
brought a
waggon of
his own in order to go
accross the Zouga at its lower end
with the intention to and of proceedinging up along
the Northern bank till we gained
the Tamunakle ˄ and of then ascending that river
to Sebituane in the North - Sekomi
had given orders to fill up the wells
which we had dug with so much
labour at Serotli, So we took
the more Eastern route through
the Bamangwuato town byand by
Letloche - That chief asked why
I had avoided him in our former
journey and when I replied that
my reason was the knowledge
that ˄ I knew he did not wish me to go
to the Lake, and I did not wish to
quarrel with him, ˄ "Well" he said "Well
you beat me and I am content"

Parting with Sechele at the ford
as he was eager to visit Lechulatebe
we went along the Northern woody
bank of the Zouga with
great labour, in cuttinghaving to cut down
148 151
trees to allow the waggons to pass -
Our losses by oxen falling into
pitfalls were very greatheavy - The
Bayeiye kindly opened them
when they knew of our approach
But when that was not the case
we could not blame no one but
ourselves on finding an established
custom of the country inimical
to our interests - On approaching
the confluence of the Tamunakle
we were informed that the fly
called Tsetse abounded on its
banks - This was a barrier we
never expected to meet - and as
it couldmight have brought our
waggons to a complete stand in
the wilderness where no supplies for children
could be obtained we were
reluctantly compelled to recross
the Zouga - From the Bayeiye
we learned that a party of
Englishmen who had come
to the Lake in search of ivory
were all laid downlow by fever
so we travelled hastily down
about 60 miles to render
what aid was in our power
Mr Alfred Rider A an enterprising young artist who had come
to make sketches of this country
and the Lake
immediately
after its discovery had died of the ˄ disease
before our arrival, but by the
aid of medicines and such
comforts as could be made by
the only English lady who ever
visited the Lake the others
149 152
happily recovered - The unfinished of ˄ drawing of
Lake Ngami is his
production just before his death
has been
kindly furnished
lent byfor
this work
by his bereaved
mother
# Sechele used all his
powers aofnd eloquence with
Lechulatebe to induce him
to furnish guides that I might
be able to visit Sebituane on
ox back, while Mrs L.Livingstone and the
children remained at Lake Ngami
He yielded - I had a very superior
London made gun the gift of
LieuttLieutenant Arkwright on which I
placed the greaterst value both on
account of the donor and the
impossibility of my replacing
it - Lechulatebe fell violently
in love with it - and offered
whatever number of elephantselephants'
tusks I should ask for it - and
would furnish Mrs L.Livingstone with
meat all the time of my absence
This latter ˄ argument made me yield too
And though he had no ivory
at the time to pay me I felt
the piece would be well spent
on these terms and delivered it ˄ to him - All being ready
for ˄ our departure I took Mrs L.Livingstone
down six miles that she might
have a peep at the broad part
of the Lake - She did not turn
up the white of her eyes nor act
the sentimental noany more than
I had myself done the year
before - And next morning
we had other work to do then
part, for our little boy & girl
150 153 65
were seized with fever - On the
day following all our servants
lay down too with ˄ the same com-
-plaint - As nothing is better
in these cases than change of
place I was forced to give up
the hope of seeing Sebituane
that year so leaving my
gun as part payment for
guides next year I leftwe started for
the pure air of the Desert - Some
mistake had happened in
the agreement with Mr OswelOswell
for we met him on the Zouga
on our return, and he devoted
the rest of this season to Elephant
hunting at which the natives
universally declare he is the
greatest adept that ever
came into the country - He
hunts without dogs - and it is
remarkable that this lordly animal
is so completely harassed by the
presence of a few yelping curs
as to be quite incapable of
attending to man - He He It makes
awkward attempts to crush them
by falling on his his its knees - and
sometimes places his his its forehead
against to a tree ten inches in diameter;
glancing atby on one side & then on, by the
other he he ^ the elephant pushes it down
before him as if he thought
thereby to catch him enemies
The only danger the huntsman
151 154
apprehends is the dogs running
towards him - and thereby
leading the elephant to their
master

Foiled in this second attempt
to reach Sebituane we returned
again to Kolobeng, whither we
were soon followed by a number
of messengers from that chief
himself - When he heard of our
attempts to visit him he despatched
three detachments of his men
with thirteen brown cows to
Lechulatebe - thirteen white ˄ cows to
Sekomi and thirteen black
cows to Sechele with the a
request to each to assist
the white men to reach him -
Their policy however was to keep
him out of view and act as his
agents in purchasing with his
ivory the goods he wanted -
The policy is thoroughly African
and that continent being without
friths and arms of the sea as
Europe is, the tribes in the centre
have always been delivered from
European intercourse by its
universal prevalence among
all the tribespeople around the coasts
Before setting out on our third
and successful journey to
Sebituane - - it was necessary
152 155
to visit Kuruman and Sechele
eager for the sake
of the commission
thereon to obtainget the ivory of that
chief into his own hands allowed
all the messengers to leave
before our return - Sekomi
however was more than usually
gracious and even furnished
us with a guide but Nono one
knew the path beyond Nchokotsa
which we intended to follow -
When we reached that point
we found that the main spring
of the gun of another of his men
who was well acquainted with
the Bushman through whose
country we should pass, had
opportunely broken - I never
undertook to mend a gun
with greater zest than this -
for under a
promise of
this ^ And as by this his guidance we went
(to the North from instead of Westward
to the Lake - All the other guides
were most liberally rewarded
by Mr OswelOswell -

We passed quickly over a
hard country which is perfectly
flat - A little soil lying on
over a tract of several hundreds of miles of calcareous
tufa supports a vegetation
of fine sweet short grass, and
Mopane and Baobab trees
InOn several parts of this we
found large salt pans, one
of which Ntwetwe is 15
miles broad & 100 long -
1523 156
The latitude might have been
taken on its horizon as well
as upon the sea -

Although these curious
spots seem perfectly level, all
those in this direction have a
gentle slope to the North East
Thither the rain water which
sometimes covers them gently
graduates - This it may be
recollected is the direction
of the Zouga - The salt dissolved
in the water had by this
means all been translated to one
pan in that direction named Tlanye
Chuantsa, on it we see a cake of salt
and lime onean inch & a half inches
thick - All the others have
an efflorescence of lime and
one of the nitrates only - and
some are covered so thickly
with shells identical with
those that now livengliving in the
Lake and ˄ the Zouga they feel
quite crisp beneath the feet -
There are three varieties
spiral
2 bivalve
univalve

1554 157
In every salt pan in the country
there is a spring of water on
one side - I can remember
no exception to this rule - The
water of these springs is brackish
and contains the nitrate of soda
In one instance there are two ˄ springs and
one more saltish than the other
If this supply came from beds
of rock salt it would ˄ not be
potable as it generally is - And in
some instances in whichwhere the salt
contained in the pan, in which
these springs appear, has been
removed by human agency
no fresh deposit occurs
It is therefore probable that these
deposits of salt are the remains
of the very slightly brackish Lakes
of antiquity large portions of
which must have been
dried out in the general desic-
-cation - This view seems
supported by the fact that the
largest quantities of salt have
been found in the hollows
or lowest valleys which have
no outlet or outgoing gorge - ^
When theythese deposits ^ occur in a flat
tufaceous country like the present a
large space is devoid of vegetation
move this
forward
to the end of
next paragraph on account of the nitrates
dissolving the tufa and keeping
it in a state unfavourable to
the growth of plants
1565 158 70
And a fountain about 30 miles
South of the Bamangwato -
The temperature of which is
upwards of one 100° - and while
strongly impregnated with pure
salt but being on a flat
part of the country is accompanied by
no deposit -

We found a ˄ great number of
wells in this tufa - A place
called Matlomagan-yana
or the "Links" is quite a
chain of these never failing
springs - As they occasionally
fill in seasons when no
rain falls and resemble
somewhat in this respect
the rivers we have already
mentioned it is probable
they recievereceive some water by
percolation from the river
system in the country beyond - Among these
links we found many
families of Bushmen and
unlike those on the plains
of the Kalahari who are
generally of short stature &
light yellow colour, these
were tall strapping fellows
and of dark complexion -
Heat alone does not produce
blackness ˄ of skin but heat with
1576 159
moisture seems to insure the
deepest hue - ᒥOne of these Bushmen
named Shobo consented to be
our guide over the waste
between these springs and the
country of Sebituane - Shobo
gave us no hope of water forin
less than a month - We came
Providentially, however ˄ we came sooner than we
expected to some Providential
supplies of rain water in a
chain of pools - Beyond these
iIt is impossible to convey
an idea of the dreary scene of
on which we entered
after leaving this spot low scrub in deep sand - We
Not a bird or insect enlivened
the landscape - It was without
exception the most uninviting
prospect I ever beheld, and
to make matters worse our
Guide Shobo wandered on the
seon˄ddaysecond day - We coaxed him on
at night but he went to all
points of the compass on the
trails of elephants which
had been here in the rainy
season, and then would sit
down in the path & in his
broken Sichuana say - "All water
all country only" -, "Shobo sleeps",
he breaks down "country only"
and then cooly curl himself up
and go to sleep - The oxen
were terribly fatigued & thirsty
1587 160 72
and on the morning of the fourth
day Shobo after professing
ignorance of every thing
vanished altogether - We went
on in the direction in which
we last saw him - and about
eleven oclocko'clock began to see
birds - Then the trail of a
Rhinoceros - at this we unyoked
the oxen and they apparently
knowing the sign rushed
along to find the water in
QuQuery meaning the River Mababe which comes
from the
Tamunakle
and lay to
the West of us . by the afternoon -
The supply of water in the waggons
had been wasted by ˄ aone of our servants
and only a small portion
remained next morning for the
children - This was a bitterly
anxious night: and next
morning the less the water
was the more thirsty the rogues
became - The idea of their
perishing before our eyes
was terrible - It would ˄ almost have
been a relief ˄ to me to have been
reproached with being the
entire cause of the catastrophe
but not one syllable of that
upbraiding was uttered bynature came from their mother
though the tearful eye told the
agony within - In the afternoon
of the fifth day to our in-
expressible relief some of the
